title: The January 2022 Hunga eruption cooled the Southern Hemisphere in 2022 and 2023
summary: The 2022 Hunga eruption of underwater volcano Hunga Tonga–Hunga Haʻapai did not warm the planet as was expected but actually reduced temperatures over the Southern Hemisphere by 0.1 C.
bottom: The Hunga Tonga produced a temporary cooling (~−0.10 K) in 2022 and 2023, challenging early projections.

title: Warm vs. Cold Rain in Storms
summary: Storm simulations reveal warm‑rain processes form up to ~80% of precipitation when cloud bases warm to ~20 °C; cold‑base storms remain ice‑dominated.
bottom: Cloud‑base warming (~10–20 K) shifts precipitation toward warm‑rain (~80%).

title: Volcanic Umbrella Clouds: Insights from Hunga Tonga
summary: Satellite observations captured record 31 km umbrella clouds with dual ice‑rich layers during Hunga Tonga eruption, redefining eruption‑impact models.
bottom: Record‑high volcanic clouds (~31 km) reshape understanding of eruption climate effects.

title: Ice Multiplication in Convective Storms
summary: Secondary ice production peaks (×10³) near −12 °C cloud tops; fragmentation & Hallett‑Mossop processes dominate, influencing precipitation dynamics.
bottom: Ice multiplication peak (~10³) at −12 °C is critical for precipitation forecasts.

title: Biological Aerosols and Ice Formation in Clouds
summary: Model simulations show 100–1000× higher biological aerosols change ice numbers by < 6% and precipitation by < 4%, due to dominant secondary‑ice processes.
bottom: Biological aerosols minimally affect cloud microphysics and precipitation (< 6%).

title: Stratocumulus Clouds and Their Climate Impact
summary: Multi‑year CloudSat & CALIPSO analysis (2006–2010) over subtropical oceans shows nighttime thickening of marine stratocumulus (~960–1200 m) boosts long‑wave warming by 10–20 W m⁻².
bottom: Night‑time thickening enhances stratocumulus warming effect (~10–20 W m⁻²).
